utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Juan Williams along with Emily Compagno, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” President Trump confirming a large-scale immigration crackdown will begin this weekend. Major cities are preparing for ICE raids on Sunday, targeting thousands of illegal immigrants, the president defending the operation.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: People come into our country illegally, we're taking them out legally. But the Democrats should be doing now is they should be changing the loopholes. They should be changing asylums. We have millions of people standing online waiting to become citizens of this country. It's not fair that somebody walks across the line and now they become citizens of the United States. Nothing to be secret about. If the world gets out, it gets out. We're taking them out by the thousands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Democrats are furious with the president's plan, Nancy Pelosi now being criticized for giving illegal immigrants this advice.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: An ICE deportation warrant is not the same as a search warrant. If that is the only document ICE brings to a home raid, agents do not have the legal right to enter a home. If ICE agents don't have a warrant signed by a judge a person may refuse to open the door and let them in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Joy Behar also causing controversy by comparing the upcoming raid to what happened in Nazi Germany.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Trump intends to move forward with his immigration raids targeting migrant families this weekend. I thought it was supposed to be gangs coming from these places, not families with children. He's going to, you know, raid these people's houses and what have you. It's really reminiscent of Nazi Germany, just saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. So this is like an intense moment. So, Jesse, let's just start with the Pelosi, you know, advice to people who are here illegally that they don't have to respond to a simple immigration warrant, that they need a search warrant to open the door. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: So you have congresswoman saying don't follow and comply with the law that Congress pass. Everything that's happening here is completely legal. If you have an illegal immigrant crossing the border that gets caught by border patrol you detained them, you process them, they get a hearing in front of an immigration judge. If they apply for asylum or they just want to come here for work, the judge says, yes, you can stay or no, and issues a deportation hearing -- proceeding. Then, ICE will come, because they do interior enforcement to a house, apprehend and deport. That's the law that Congress passed years ago. The executive branch is enforcing that law. And the judge is signing off on everything. So you have the executive, judicial and legislative branches all working together harmoniously, but you have Democrats saying, don't follow the laws of our country. They want American citizens to follow the laws, but they don't want illegal aliens. This one you have to think, do they want any enforcement? They don't want it in the interior. They don't want it at the border. They don't want you to have to stay in a country that you are and apply. When you get there, they don't want you detained. If you commit a crime in a sanctuary city, they don't want to let ICE know about it. They don't even want the federal government to ask you a question, are you a U.S. citizen? But want they do want, they want to give you an American job, they want to give you a driver's license, in-state college tuition, and they want to give you free health insurance. So at this point, the Democrats are the party of open borders and that's just a fact.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Just a quick question on this. Isn't it the case that she's saying, here is the law as it's written? She's not saying violate the law, she's saying follow the law. WATTERS: No, if you are issued a deportation order from a judge in America, you have to follow that order.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, OK. Dana, so what we're also seeing is that Hillary Clinton, as well as Pelosi are saying, hey, this is heartless, people go to church on Sunday and you're breaking down doors?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, is that -- that's really -- oh, OK. All right, got it. So neglecting to enforce the law for a couple of decades on these enforcement orders means that this problem just gets harder. And unless America is going to say, OK, then everybody is here illegally, you can stay. If we're going to say that, then we should have that debate. And then the laws would have to change. I don't think anybody is actually saying that. The fact that we have so many illegal immigrants here, that is hurting people who want immigrate here legally. The number of stories of people who are stuck in the process, who are stuck in the paperwork because there's not enough resources to figure out how to get them here legally. We need people to come here. We need people to come and work and to -- want to raise their families here. I would also say that like with what Joy Behar said, it's so atrocious because Jews were targeted because of who they were, not because of what they had done. That was -- these were citizens of Germany, they were paying taxes -- comparing -- again, comparing Nazi Germany to this is really bad. President Trump also said today, we are going -- we're focused on criminals as much as we can and I believe that, because the Department of Homeland Security is under such extreme scrutiny and they've telegraphed for six weeks that these raids are coming, that imagine how everyone is going to be out and about in these cities ready to film anything to try to catch anything that would make it look like they're being insensitive. And it is going to be heart-wrenching, people are here for a long time, they have ties, but if they've committed a crime in the United States, and they have a deportation order, and the President of the United States decides to execute on those orders, then I think they have to follow the law. For as hard as it might be to watch, it is actually what needs to be done. And the fact that we have not done it for decades means it just gets worse the longer we don't do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, Greg, so yesterday we had the news that the president was not going to try -- continue his efforts to put a question about citizenship status on the census.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, is this now just a political step to say, hey, Democrats, you better get on board and start doing what I want, and the illegal immigrants are the ones who are going to feel the brunt of this over the weekend?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, before I go any further, I'd like to be sworn in.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We usually don't require that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But, no, I want to be sworn in, damn-it, OK. To the point about yesterday or whatever day it was, I love this solution, using databases that we already have. It totally destroys all of the objections about it, violating this or violating that, and it maybe more accurate to answering the census question. That's pretty bad ass, I have to say. He's not President Trump, he's President MacGyver. He figured out a way to solve the problem with the tools that he had. And only somebody who's been in business understands this. Politicians stop there and focus on this problem for so long, and he says I'll just go around back and fix this myself. He is solving these problems using two key movers in human nature. One of them is fairness and the other is incentive. Fairness, people who did it the right way, people who waited in line, it is not fair to cut in line, that is -- everybody understands that, especially minorities who come from other countries who waited in line. The process matters, because then everybody is treated fairly. That's human nature, incentive. What he's doing right now is predicated on the Republican disincentive. Word gets out that we're going to deport people who are there illegally disincentives people from coming here. It's the opposite of waiving caravans through. So these are two things that human beings understand, fairness and incentive. These are two things that the Democrats can't get into their thick skulls, and that's why they're losing the American public and they're devouring themselves. And now I would like to be sworn in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Emily, one of the questions about this is if you are going after people who are undocumented and haven't shown up for court dates, is it possible that you then sweep up people who really have been living here, families together, done nothing wrong, I mean, in fact, paying taxes and working, but they're going to get swept up in all of the activity this weekend.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.utterance: I think that's true, too, and unrelated, if you mean swept up that they are the subject of final deportation orders, then that's the whole point. And to respond to what both of you guys were saying, I think that the outcry over the enforcement of the existing laws ignores the fact that there are built in safety features within the process itself, the final deportation order means that all appeals have been exhausted. Even if the immigrants just reserved or waves -- or reserves the right to appeal, that automatically stays the entire proceeding. There are more safety features built in. So are we calling into question the judges' order, the judges' judgment? Are we calling into question the policies, the 90 days that ICE has to then deport? Like, if so, then let's change it, congress-people or voters, or what else do our tax dollars pay for? There are estimates of hundreds of thousands, if not one million, that are here with final deportation orders --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A million?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- for us -- yes. For us to ignore that or for us to pick and choose what laws that we want to enforce, why then would we pick and choose every other law. So when you say that it's up to us to basically exemplify a model what's going on, like, absolutely, because what other message are we sending? And I would think that it would be incumbent upon all of us to appreciate that, because the rest of us that are here should know that our government does prioritize enforcing laws, because otherwise shouldn't I be scared 24 hours a day that anything could happen --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- because a Democrat said, oh, no, no, no, but not this one. It's a Sunday, no thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Coming up, “The Five” -- huh, “The Five” turned eight, by that I mean we're 8-years-old. We haven't been able to celebrate because yesterday was so much news. So we're going to have a celebration today. You don't want to miss it. But first, earlier this week he defended his handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case, but today Alex Acosta has resigned as labor secretary, the latest fallout from the scandal when “The Five” returns.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Major developments in the growing Jeffrey Epstein's scandal, Labor Secretary Alex Acosta announcing he's stepping down. Acosta has been facing a firestorm of criticism over his role in a controversial 2008 plea deal with Epstein. After defending himself earlier this week, here's Acosta explaining why he's resigning.

utterances.speaker: ALEX ACOSTA, LABOR SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: It would be selfish for me to stay in this position and continue talking about a case that's 12-years-old rather than about the amazing economy we have right now. And so I submitted my resignation to the president effective seven days from today. Going forward, that's what this administration needs to focus, not on this matter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump defending Acosta from the wave of attacks, and also distancing himself from Epstein.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: I think he was a great labor secretary, not a good labor secretary. He's done a fantastic job. He's doing this not for himself. He's doing this for the administration. And, Alex, I think you'll agree, I said you don't have to do this. He doesn't have to do this. I was not a fan of Jeffrey Epstein. Other people they went all over with him, they went to his island. Find out the people that went to the island. But, Jeffrey Epstein was not somebody that I respected.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, first, Greg, you never see a cabinet secretary resign right next to the president --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? I love his reason for leaving, that is the perfect way to get out of a relationship, you know, it would be selfish of me to stay with you. I'm only bringing you down. It's better if I just leave. And can I have the phone number of your friend you're jogging with earlier?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not you, it's me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's me, OK. So this just shows -- it doesn't stop when you lose an election, it sucks when you win, because in the other side shifts into scalp mode, right? Who can they get? And Trump is the bull's-eye, right? Impeachment. But the target keeps getting wider, include cabinet members, family members, but also people in red hat supporters, people who makes memes. Everybody is a target. What kills me about this is how the media is framing this. So what interests them is how did Acosta go out? Was he pushed out or did he leave on his own? No, it was the media and their nonstop focus on Acosta, not Epstein that forced his hand. Again, only the media could make a Democratic pedophile a Republican problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan -- that's a good point. You saw the president mentioned not by name, but potentially Bill Clinton flying around in a jet of Epstein. We want to know did he go to that island that a lot of nefarious things were happening --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pedophile Island they call it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. We've seen flight records showing former president taking at least 26 trips. The president says that was actually four trips. There's a splitting hair over the actual amount of flights, but shouldn't the media and, you know, Democrats be concerned whether or not President Bill Clinton was palling around without secret service as being reported with a pedophile.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The secret service had said he went nowhere without their detail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, there's a debate about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, all right. I just know that's what they've said in their statement. So here's the thing, I think that Republicans are running away from the fact that this guy knew President Trump far longer --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, wait, Juan --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's about a Republican.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is. It's about President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's a Democratic donor. He's a Democratic donor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See, he's a donor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just telling you that he is the labor secretary for this president.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, Acosta --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Acosta.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Epstein and Clinton, and you're talking about Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because I'm talking about the resignation today, Acosta -- and I'm saying --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, go ahead. Ask anything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you concerned about Bill Clinton's relationship --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm concerned --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And do you think it should be investigated because there's not a lot of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Of course, everybody is investigating that. That's not the issue. To me, the news here today is I see the President on the United States, I see Acosta and they're all saying -- you know, Acosta, you're a great labor secretary, which is total nonsense, because, guess what, his buddies including the chief of staff are all telling this guy, hey, you've to go. You're a problem. You're a distraction. Guess what? He was a distraction earlier in the week when Chris Reddy and everybody else --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan is not addressing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think Trump is doing nothing but protecting his friends, and not a word about the victims. Oh, I feel sorry for Acosta --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's so sweet of you, Juan. So sweet of you to care about the victims.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you don't.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The biggest issue with politicizing this entire thing is just that, that you ignored every voice that has been shouting about this literally for years. And the things that the left is pouncing on right now in every headline that you see in the print format it's labor -- you know, the labor secretary and this and that. It's totally shifting the spotlight away from the pedophile, away from that plea agreement, that if it does raise your eyebrows, and if you do have issues with it, then you should participate in the criminal justice system to know why it should be changed, and proceed further into all of the participants with that agreement, and for so many years, including in this state federally and locally. So they're just so many moving parts that as always get ignored because of the clamoring of the media that's trying to drag on Trump's heels, and also because of the left that's trying to put this on the person that doesn't deserve the spotlight like a tenth of as much as Epstein does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana, final thoughts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think when Alex Acosta, his press conference, kept saying that things are different now, that was the clue that the media was not going to -- the media might never have stopped. But when he said things are different now -- well, no, human trafficking and pedophilia that's not different. Maybe he didn't mean that. But I think that he was definitely going to continue to have to answer these questions every day, and sometimes the best thing that you can do is walk away from even from a job that you really like. I thought that was pretty nice of President Trump to do that, and to give him a pretty nice send-off. He didn't get the oval office treatment like Nikki Haley, but he certainly wasn't just kicked out without any, sort of, like handshake, goodbye. I think Scott Pruitt when he left, he didn't get anything like that. So Alex Acosta leaves under a little bit of a cloud, but I don't think because of how he did as labor secretary, those are new complaints from the people in the administration saying he wasn't going far enough, fast enough. The economy is obviously doing very well. And I don't know what would be next for him, thought. I think it will be hard to land somewhere right away.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that Vice President Haley that you were referring to who got the oval office?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very funny, Juan. Up next, why L.A. better prepare for the plague. See the dire warning about the city's homeless crisis up next.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The homeless crisis in Los Angeles is continuing to spiral out of control and local politicians are doing little to stop it. They claim one of the primary causes is a lack of affordable housing. But Dr. Drew Pinsky is speaking out and debunking that narrative. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This isn't a housing --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's not --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That's a hoax. That's a hoax being perpetrated by our government here locally.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But it seems like --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Of course, we have housing expense issues, but we just observed a million illegal undocumented immigrants. They've found a place to live. It's a hoax. So it's a mental health crisis and addiction crisis. People that had mental illnesses that should been imprisoned in the first place, frankly, ended up on the streets. And then because we made drugs legal essentially in California, all my people are here. The drug users are here now, because they don't get hassled.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Dr. Drew also sounding the alarm about L.A.'s growing public health emergency, and he's warning about the possibility of a deadly disease outbreak.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The people go, why are you so concerned now at this? One word, rats. We have been -- if you've seen what's happened with the rats? We have like 12 million rats in Los Angeles now. And the last time we had more than 2 million, plague broke out.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg, communicable diseases and rats don't care about city limits. And they don't care about whether Democrats or Republicans leading them. So what's going to happen when they start -- and, oh, by the way, later on he said -- Dr. Drew said something about if only 2 percent of those --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's scary.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's frightening. It's a total -- remember that movie Outbreak? It's that. So tell us about --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Twelve million rats, but enough about the Hollywood actors. This, you know -- Dr. Drew is scaring the crap out of me, and he scares the crap out of me because he's always right. He's predicted all these disease outbreaks in the last couple of years. You know, it usually happens after a mass disaster like an earthquake. In countries like Haiti, for example, when they have terrible infrastructure, you have bodies that rot, you have -- and then you have rats, and then you have disease. That's what you're having in L.A. And that's not a natural disaster. You want a man-made disaster, this is man-made. It's three issues and he's nailed it, mental health issues, drug issues, and an incentive to stay. The incentive to stay is we're not gonna bug you, we're gonna let you go. Dr. Drew sent that email out to us about how the fire department comes in and tries to clean it up, but what they end up doing as they hose the human fesses and the drugs into the water. Sixty thousand people, their stuff goes into the water. My suggestion and what Trump should do is he should declare an emergency and appoint Drew as like a homeless czar, right? Create like -- I'm serious, create like a team that has a Doctor Marc Seagull, Bill Pulte. Have these people that are interested in solving problems. Bill Pulte is tackling the blithe in Detroit. People that aren't political. These are not political people. Get an engineer involved that can figure out how to build these shelters to get these people in, because they're not using the shelters in L.A. the way they use them in New York. Something like 5 percent I got from Dr. Siegel. So, I don't know. I think there's a way to do this. I think Trump should attack it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Dana, what's going to be the wake-up call?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, when he says that if the rat population -- like 1.5 percent of the rats have plague now. And so when it gets to 2 percent, that's when it jumps to humans. Like, that would be a wake-up call.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean that's not going to go too well, indeed. And also he said that -- I think it's interesting that he said that the legal is -- the relaxing the law on drugs have caused an additional problem. Basically you have states all across America that have that on the ballot saying like, oh, we think that this is a really great idea for civil liberties perspective, but, you know, maybe be careful what you wish for.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Because all of those issues are interrelated, too. So I think it's impossible to contain one without affecting the other. Jesse, you had some creative ideas yesterday that we --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. Those were not creative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Cool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those were terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a temporary solution to a problem if you have a business and you have a tent city.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Outside your family business. Have a little sprinkler system then maybe wet them and then move them or loud music or loud canines. But I agree with every point that Greg made, and the Dr. Drew made, you have a toxic combination of factors and a permissive political structure that's not going to do anything. They tried to quarantine them into these zombie zones. Then now there is spillover from the zones and it's affecting police and families and small businesses. The point is the czar thing could work, but you have to have Democrat buy in. You have to have some Democrat buy in, in California or they're not going to allow these experts from the Trump team to parachute in and try to fix the problem that they helped create. I haven't heard a thing from Democrats running for president about this issue, this very issue. I've heard a lot about compassion for illegal immigrants, not a lot of compassion for American citizens that are living right under their noses. And that's why a lot of Americans are upset with the Democratic Party because they feel like they care more about other people than they care about the people living under their own border. They haven't heard anything in the media about this. Where is CNN? Where is MSNBC? It seems like the national media also doesn't care about it, just like they don't care about black on black crime in the south of Chicago, just don't like they care about other issues that make them look bad politically.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't understand Jesse, compassion. If you're saying that they lack compassion. A minute ago, I thought you said that they were too compassionate and that's why the people were--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know, I think you need tough love. I don't think it's compassionate to just let people decay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't either.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Any street.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But let me just say, I don't think that - I agree with Greg. I think the President should act. I think if you consider this a national issue, if you're not simply trying to attack cities and Democrats and somehow responsible. Well, then OK, it's a national issue, individuals like us can't specifically do any one thing. You know I think we can feel very self-conscious and uptight about seeing so many homeless people on the street. But it's going to take a national solution. I disagree about sending in radio talk show host and TV personnel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's a doctor. He's actually a doctor, who has dealt with infectious disease and drug addiction. Dr. Drew is not a talk show.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. I get - that's all I know; talk shows and I get really upset when I hear that this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is diminishing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Issue gets boiled down to like the threat, the fear mongering of well, this could lead to bubonic plague.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh! My God. This is terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what after the show, you should read up on Dr. Drew's history--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That he has treated thousands of patients for decades. I know you don't want the facts, Juan. You don't care. You just want to demean somebody.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What we are saying here today to this audience--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Those people that you see on the street--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're the reason people suffer; you don't want to help them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Health risk the rats are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just think rats are a problem. I don't care about homeless. You can go to big cities everywhere and there is a rat problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh! Geez.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right you guys. Viewers stay right there. Fan Mail Friday is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which show is this, SWAT.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: SWAT.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or the Rookies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Fan Mail Friday. Let's get to it, Facebook question from James H. You must complete one of the following to remain on “The Five.” Shark cage, bungee jump or jumping out of a plane. Which is it? I don't really a why. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Plane.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Plane, parachute.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I could do it with somebody else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. How about you, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to think what the safest is and I'm going to go with shark cage.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Were you not claustrophobic?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm great underwater.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you love putting people in cages, don't you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Watters World.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Typical Trump supporter. Chooses the cage. Juan, what about you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And you got to worry that the shark might break the cage.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it'll be very real--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We'll try to separate you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's Trump steal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's like the best people like the--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan stick to the topic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, I've got to with Dana. I think - I don't know because I don't do these things, I don't even take roller coaster rides. But I do notice that a lot of senior citizens jump out of airplanes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Shark cage for sure. I've already gone skydiving. I have zero interest in bungee jumping and then the shark cage I could see the shark and see the animals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You missed the first part of the question. You must complete one of the following to remain on “The Five.” So, it's been nice knowing you guys. Because I'm not doing any of this. All right. It's a Graham question from Frenchi Firecracker. This is a great question though. What movie trope i.e. clich, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was going to ask.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know it will be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Annoys you the most. What movie trope annoys--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What would that mean? Like an example.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like a cliché, it's a thing that always happens in movies and it makes you groan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, what.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you know how like three quarters through the end of the movie you'll get one of these scenes where like the music starts playing and things get like nice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Things turn nice and like a sitcom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because they're trying to tell you how to feel.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're introducing music and when they do that in movies, I get so angry, but I'm angry all the time, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. How do we know the difference?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Do you know what - can you think of--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I feel like I haven't watched enough movies to know. In books it drives me crazy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What? Of course, it has to be in a book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Seriously Dana.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why don't you go to movies where they film people reading books.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The inability of a character to come clean like you know how the whole movie is based on like the lie that they have to play out for like 90 minutes. That's what kills me, that clich, kills me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But then they don't have the movie. That's what the guy's lying.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: No. That's what--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She is saying like--

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So annoying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's saying, why can't they get to the end faster.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Because it wasn't a good movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know what she's talking about. It's like the movie plot could be solved by doing one thing, but they don't and that's the movie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But then there is no movie. I've got it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Thankfully.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is a weird question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love this question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's kind of like Pretty Woman you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This woman who is really a bad woman and then turns out she's just--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sexist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Delightful and she gets married to the prince.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A little bit like Cinderella, but it's in lots of movies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's favorite folk story. I'm going to go with children are smart. Every freaking movie, the child in the movie is always precociously smart and always has more wisdom than the adults. When we all know children are actually snotty idiots, right. Their brain isn't formed yet, they're annoying. They're troubling. OK, next question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, are you OK?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You just don't like kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. When was the most inappropriate time you busted out laughter and why?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh! God. All the time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This happened to me yesterday, because I was on a business channel show and they started reading a Trump tweet, which he was talking about how brilliant and handsome he was and this was news, but I was like come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's - because it's funny, because it's a joke for Trump. He's having fun. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll make you know sexual double entendres accidentally on the show and Dana will have no idea what's going on and Greg and I are looking at each other like, my god.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, life for eight years that has been the story of my life.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You guys are laughing, and I don't know why.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Somewhere if I have to be super quiet and then something funny happens and I have like a complete laugh attack, because I have to be quiet, I can't laugh out loud.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what it is. Anytime we do a sentimental serious One More Thing, I'm like the kid in church who wants to scream.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I can't--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know that it's really horrible because some of this stuff is really heartwarming. But I just want to start screaming.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Especially if it involves children.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If it's children.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I can't even look at you because I will start laughing too. So- -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All this stuff that she - everybody on television thinks that heartwarming things are good. They're not. Five just turned eight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We do have issues.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And we have lots of fun for our anniversary. Coming up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, we didn't get to celebrate yesterday, so we are today. “The Five” turned eight and to kick off the party we're taking a look back at the past year.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is a Fox News Alert. Again, Robert Mueller has submitted his report on the Russian investigation to Attorney General William Barr.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fox News Alert, an explosive college admissions scandal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Control of Congress is up for grabs as millions of Americans cast their ballots in what's shaping up to be historic midterm elections.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jussie Smollett now faces a felony charge for filing a false report claiming that he was a victim.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You are looking live at a massive fire engulfing the historic Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, France.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fox News Alert, President Trump has ordered the FBI to conduct an investigation into Judge Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: After John Rich performed our song, Shut Up About Politics on the show yesterday. It reached number one on the iTunes country charts and number two overall.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
